“We ought to be trying to focus on an investigation on a professional level by Bob Mueller, and not trying to find a way to obstruct justice or to absolve this president from any responsibility he has.”

In a column for Esquire, Rep. Adam Schiff, the top Democrat in the Intelligence Committee also said the memo doesn’t vindicate Trump in any way.

Pool/Getty Images

A few Republican lawmakers walked a thin line on Sunday, subtly but clearly disagreeing with President Trump’s contention that the memo that was declassified Friday and alleges wrongdoing by the FBI vindicates the commander in chief in the special counsel’s investigation into Russian meddling in the presidential election.

“The memo’s release provided none of the vindication the President sought or would claim, but it was hugely consequential nonetheless, in how it undermined the system of checks and balances designed to insulate the FBI from White House meddling established in the wake of Watergate,” Schiff wrote.

The statements were seen as an effort to distance themselves from a tweet President Donald Trump sent on Saturday in which he said that the memo “totally vindicates ‘Trump’ in probe.”

This memo totally vindicates “Trump” in probe.

Gowdy, who is one of the four authors of the memo that was released Friday, insists that the infamous “Steele dossier” was essential to approving the surveillance warrant for former Campaign adviser Carter Page.

“This memo, frankly, has nothing at all to do with the special counsel.”

“I want to stress, Bob Mueller should be allowed to turn over every rock, pursue every lead so that we can have trust in knowing what actually the Russians did or did not do,” Hurd said on ABC’s This Week.

“I actually don’t think it has any impact on the Russia probe,” Rep. Trey Gowdy of South Carolina said on CBS’ Face the Nation.
“There is a Russia investigation without a dossier,” he said, noting that the dossier has “nothing to do” with the Trump Tower meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer.

Rep. Brad Wenstrup from Ohio also said that the memo is a “separate issue” from the Russia probe.
Four Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee said on Sunday that the controversial memo doesn’t somehow invalidate the probe that is being carried out by Robert Mueller.
